brief_summary: The Great March of Return was a series of mass demonstrations held weekly from March 30, 2018 to December 27, 2019, at five designated sites along Gaza's separation fence with Israel. Organized initially by independent activists including journalist Ahmed Abu Artema, the protests demanded Palestinian refugees' right to return to lands they were displaced from in 1948, an end to Israel's land-air-sea blockade of Gaza (in place since 2007), and opposed US recognition of Jerusalem as Israel's capital. The protests were largely peaceful, involving families, tents, speeches, and symbolic activities. Israeli forces responded with massive use of live ammunition. According to the UN Commission of Inquiry, Israeli snipers killed 189 Palestinians and wounded over 6,106 with live fire between March 30 and December 31, 2018 alone (total deaths reached 223 by end of 2019). The Commission found that in all but two cases, the use of lethal force was unlawful‚Äîprotesters did not pose imminent threat to life. Among the dead were 41 children, three clearly marked paramedics (including Razan al-Najjar), and two clearly marked journalists. The Commission concluded Israeli forces committed violations that may constitute war crimes or crimes against humanity.

paragraphs: The Great March of Return began on March 30, 2018‚ÄîPalestinian Land Day and the 42nd anniversary of mass protests against Israeli land confiscation. Organized by independent activists, the protests were conceived as peaceful demonstrations to draw international attention to Gaza's humanitarian crisis, the blockade, and the right of return for Palestinian refugees. Five designated protest sites were established along Gaza's eastern border, several hundred meters from the separation fence. The protests were intended to last from Land Day (March 30) through Nakba Day (May 15), but continued for 21 months until Hamas announced their end on December 27, 2019.

Israel's response was immediate and lethal. Israeli Defense Forces deployed snipers along the fence with rules of engagement permitting use of live ammunition against protesters. On the opening day, March 30, 2018, Israeli forces killed 18 Palestinians and shot over 700 with live ammunition. The bloodiest day came on May 14, 2018‚Äîthe day the US Embassy officially opened in Jerusalem‚Äîwhen Israeli forces killed 60 Palestinians and shot over 1,100. By December 31, 2018, Israeli snipers had shot 6,106 Palestinians with live ammunition, killing 183 during official protest days. Thirty-five were children, three were clearly marked paramedics, and two were clearly marked journalists. Another 3,098 Palestinians were injured by bullet fragmentation, rubber-coated metal bullets, or tear gas canisters.

The UN Commission of Inquiry investigated every killing at the designated demonstration sites on official protest days between March 30 and December 31, 2018. Commissioners reviewed video evidence, medical records, ballistics reports, and conducted extensive interviews. Their finding was damning: with the exception of two incidents, the Commission found reasonable grounds to believe the use of live ammunition was unlawful. The victims 'were neither participating directly in hostilities nor posing an imminent threat' when shot. Commissioner Sara Hossain stated: 'There can be no justification for killing and injuring journalists, medics, and persons who were clearly not posing an imminent threat of death or serious injury.' The Commission concluded the pattern of violations may constitute war crimes or crimes against humanity. Notable victims included 21-year-old paramedic Razan al-Najjar, shot and killed while treating wounded protesters despite wearing a clearly marked white medical vest, and journalist Yaser Murtaja, shot dead while wearing press insignia. By the time protests ended in December 2019, 223 Palestinians had been killed and 28,939 injured. At least 122 Palestinians required limb amputations including 20 children. Israel has conducted no meaningful investigations, with all but a handful of cases closed without indictment.

alert.text: Sources: UN Commission of Inquiry; B'Tselem; Palestinian Ministry of Health; WHO; UN OCHA; Defense for Children International; Physicians for Human Rights. UN Commission investigated every single killing on official protest days through Dec 31, 2018.

events.title: Planning and organization
events.description: Independent Palestinian activists including journalist Ahmed Abu Artema organize protests demanding right of return and end to blockade. Protests planned for March 30 (Land Day) through May 15 (Nakba Day). Five designated sites chosen along separation fence.

events.title: First protest - Palestinian Land Day
events.description: Approximately 30,000 Palestinians gather at five sites for opening of Great March of Return. Israeli forces kill 18 Palestinians, shoot over 700 with live ammunition on first day. UN High Commissioner for Human Rights expresses 'profound concern' about use of live ammunition.

events.title: Weekly protests continue; journalists killed
events.description: Protests held every Friday. April 6: Journalist Yaser Murtaja shot and killed while wearing PRESS vest filming protests. April 13: Journalist Ahmad Abu Hussein shot (died April 25). Both clearly marked as press. Over 40 killed in April. Israeli Defense Minister Avigdor Lieberman: 'There are no innocents in Gaza.'

events.title: UN Human Rights Council establishes Commission
events.description: Following international outcry over May 14 massacre, UN Human Rights Council passes resolution S-28/1 establishing independent Commission of Inquiry to investigate violations. Israel immediately rejects and refuses cooperation. US votes against resolution.

events.title: Deadliest day - 60 killed as US opens Jerusalem embassy
events.description: Day US Embassy officially opened in Jerusalem, over 40,000 protesters gather at fence. Israeli snipers kill 60 Palestinians, shoot over 1,100 with live fire‚Äîbloodiest day of protests. 8 of those killed were children. UN Secretary General calls for independent investigation. Israeli PM Netanyahu praises soldiers: 'Every country has the right to defend its borders.'

sourceLinks.name: UN Commission Special Section on May 14

events.title: Razan al-Najjar killed
events.description: Razan al-Najjar, 21-year-old female paramedic, shot and killed by Israeli sniper while treating wounded near Khan Yunis. Wearing clearly marked white medical vest with red crescent. Video shows her with hands raised before being shot. Israeli military initially claims she was human shield, later investigation shows no evidence supporting claim.

events.title: Commission begins field investigation
events.description: UN Commission visits Gaza and region (not Israel‚Äîaccess denied). Conducts hundreds of interviews with victims, witnesses, medical personnel. Reviews video evidence, medical records, ballistics reports. Documents every killing on official protest days.

events.title: Third medic killed; amputations mount
events.description: July 20: Abdullah al-Qutati (20), paramedic, killed. Third medical worker shot dead. WHO reports 'unprecedented' number of limb injuries requiring amputation‚Äîbullets causing extreme bone and tissue damage. Over 100 amputations performed; many more needed.

events.title: Protests continue despite casualties
events.description: Weekly protests ongoing. By September, over 180 Palestinians killed, 5,500+ shot with live fire. International attention wanes. Israeli military maintains rules of engagement unchanged. Zero Israeli casualties reported throughout entire protest period.

events.title: UN Commission releases report
events.description: Commission releases comprehensive 289-page report. Key finding: 'Reasonable grounds to believe' that in 187 of 189 cases investigated, use of live ammunition was unlawful. Victims posed no imminent threat. Violations may constitute war crimes or crimes against humanity. Recommends criminal investigations and ICC referral.

events.title: UN Human Rights Council endorses report
events.description: Human Rights Council endorses Commission report by vote of 23-8-16. Calls on Israel to comply with recommendations. Israel rejects all findings. US, Australia, Austria vote against. Many European countries abstain.

events.title: Hamas announces end to protests
events.description: After 21 months of weekly demonstrations, Hamas announces suspension of Great March of Return. Total toll: 223 Palestinians killed, 28,939 injured. Zero Israeli casualties. Protests ended with none of their stated objectives achieved: no easing of blockade, no progress on right of return.

events.title: Accountability efforts continue
events.description: Israeli military closes vast majority of investigations without indictment. Only minor charges filed in handful of cases. ICC investigation (opened 2021) includes Great March of Return. Palestinian lawyers submit evidence to ICC. Victims continue seeking justice through international mechanisms.

sourceLinks.name: Adalah - Legal Center for Arab Minority Rights

alert.text: UN Commission conclusion: 'Israeli security forces killed and gravely injured civilians who were neither participating directly in hostilities nor posing an imminent threat...Some violations may constitute war crimes or crimes against humanity.'‚ÄîChair Santiago Canton, February 2019

crimes.title: Unlawful Killings - 187 of 189 Cases
crimes.description: UN Commission investigated every killing at designated protest sites on official protest days (Mar 30-Dec 31, 2018). Found 'reasonable grounds to believe' 187 of 189 killings were unlawful under international law. Victims 'neither participating directly in hostilities nor posing imminent threat to life' when shot. Intentional lethal force against civilians not posing imminent threat constitutes willful killing‚Äîwar crime under Geneva Conventions.

crimes.title: Targeting of Medical Personnel
crimes.description: Three paramedics killed (Razan al-Najjar, Musa Abu Hassanein, Abdullah al-Qutati), 441 wounded despite clear identification with white medical vests marked with red crescent/cross. All were providing medical care and posed no threat. Intentional attacks on medical personnel are grave breaches of Geneva Conventions. UN: 'no justification' for these killings.

crimes.title: Killing and Wounding of Journalists
crimes.description: Two journalists killed (Yaser Murtaja, Ahmad Abu Hussein), 144 injured. Both killed journalists clearly wearing PRESS identification. Committee to Protect Journalists: 'Deliberately targeting journalists is a war crime.' Targeting clearly identified journalists violates IHL protections for civilians not taking part in hostilities.

crimes.title: Killing of 41 Children
crimes.description: 41 children (ages 8 months to 17 years) killed. UN Commission found in vast majority of cases, children posed no imminent threat when shot. Leila al-Ghandour (8 months) died from tear gas exposure. Others shot with live ammunition. Willful killing of protected persons (children) is grave breach of Fourth Geneva Convention.

crimes.title: Deliberate Targeting of Lower Limbs
crimes.description: Pattern of intentional shooting at lower limbs documented‚Äî6,106 shot with live fire, majority in legs. WHO documented 'unprecedented' limb injuries requiring 122+ amputations (20 children). Physicians for Human Rights: bullets 'designed to cause maximum tissue and bone damage.' Intentionally causing severe injury amounting to torture or cruel treatment‚Äîpotential war crime.

crimes.title: Excessive and Indiscriminate Use of Force
crimes.description: May 14, 2018: 60 killed, 1,100+ shot in single day. No Israeli casualties throughout entire 21-month period demonstrates force was not in response to imminent threat. UN: Use of lethal force was 'disproportionate' and 'not strictly necessary.' Indiscriminate firing into crowds of civilians violates fundamental IHL principles.
crimes.sourceText: üìÑ UN Commission Special Section on May 14 ‚Üë

crimes.title: Unlawful Rules of Engagement
crimes.description: Israeli military rules of engagement authorized snipers to use live ammunition against protesters not posing imminent threat. Rules permitted shooting persons approaching fence, damaging it, or setting tires alight‚Äînone constitute imminent threat to life. Rules of engagement that authorize unlawful killings may constitute superior orders to commit war crimes.

crimes.title: Possible Crimes Against Humanity
crimes.description: UN Commission: Given pattern, scale, and systematic nature of violations‚Äî223 killed, 28,939 injured over 21 months‚Äîviolations may constitute crimes against humanity. Elements include: widespread or systematic attack against civilian population, knowledge of attack, and underlying acts (murder, torture). Commission recommended ICC investigation.

international_law.title: International Law Framework
international_law.introduction: The Great March of Return occurred under framework of international human rights law and international humanitarian law. UN Commission concluded Israeli forces' actions violated both legal frameworks.

sections.heading: Use of Force - International Human Rights Law
violations: Right to Life (ICCPR Article 6): Intentional use of lethal force only permissible when 'strictly necessary' to protect life from imminent threat. UN found in 187 of 189 cases, victims posed no such threat‚Äîviolations of right to life.

Basic Principles on Use of Force (UN 1990): 'Intentional lethal use of firearms may only be made when strictly unavoidable in order to protect life.' Commission found force was not unavoidable; no Israeli casualties demonstrate absence of threat.

Arbitrary Deprivation of Life: Willful killings without legal justification constitute arbitrary deprivation of life. UN Human Rights Committee: States must investigate all killings by security forces.

Prohibition of Torture: Intentional shooting to cause severe limb injuries (122+ amputations) may constitute torture or cruel, inhuman treatment prohibited under ICCPR Article 7 and Convention Against Torture.

sections.heading: International Humanitarian Law - Fourth Geneva Convention
violations: Article 27 (Protected Persons): Civilians 'shall be treated humanely...protected against all acts of violence.' Shooting civilians not posing imminent threat violates this core protection.
Article 147 (Grave Breaches): 'Wilful killing...torture...wilfully causing great suffering or serious injury' are grave breaches. 223 killings, 28,939 injuries, 122+ amputations meet this threshold.
Protected Categories: Geneva Conventions specifically protect medical personnel (Article 20) and journalists as civilians. Killing 3 medics and 2 journalists are grave breaches.
Children: Fourth Geneva Convention Article 24 and Additional Protocol I Article 77 provide special protection for children. Killing 41 children violates these protections.

sections.heading: UN Commission of Inquiry Findings (February 2019)
violations: Unlawful Killings: '187 of 189' killings investigated found unlawful. Victims 'neither participating directly in hostilities nor posing imminent threat of death or serious injury.'
War Crimes: Commission found 'reasonable grounds to believe' Israeli forces committed violations amounting to war crimes, including willful killing and torture/cruel treatment.
Crimes Against Humanity: Given widespread and systematic nature of attack against civilian population, Commission found violations may constitute crimes against humanity.

Command Responsibility: Violations resulted from policy decisions at highest levels. Rules of engagement approved by senior military and political leadership may establish command responsibility for war crimes.

sections.heading: Specific Protections Violated
violations: Medical Personnel: Hague Convention IV (1907) and Geneva Conventions mandate protection of medical personnel. Shooting 3 clearly marked paramedics and wounding 441 medical workers violates this absolute protection.
Journalists: Additional Protocol I Article 79 affords journalists protection as civilians. Intentional targeting of 2 clearly marked journalists constitutes war crime.
Distinction Principle: Fundamental IHL principle requires distinction between combatants and civilians. Shooting unarmed civilians, children, medics, journalists violates this bedrock principle.
Proportionality: Even if some individuals posed threat, killing 60 in single day (May 14) with zero Israeli casualties demonstrates grossly disproportionate response.

alert.text: Total impunity: Despite UN findings, Israeli military closed vast majority of cases without indictment. Only minor charges in handful of cases unrelated to killings. ICC investigation ongoing but no charges filed as of 2025.

witnesses.name: Santiago Canton
witnesses.testimony: In presenting final report February 2019: 'The Commission found reasonable grounds to believe that Israeli snipers shot at journalists, health workers, children and persons with disabilities, knowing they were clearly recognizable as such...Israeli soldiers killed and gravely injured civilians who were neither participating directly in hostilities nor posing an imminent threat...Some of these violations may constitute war crimes or crimes against humanity.'

witnesses.name: Sara Hossain
witnesses.testimony: Commissioner statement: 'There can be no justification for the killing and maiming of clearly identifiable journalists, medics, and persons who were clearly not posing an imminent threat of death or serious injury. The Commission found that Israeli security forces killed and gravely injured protestors who did not pose an imminent threat of death or serious injury to others when they were shot.'

witnesses.name: Rawan al-Najjar (Razan's mother)
witnesses.testimony: After daughter Razan shot June 1, 2018: 'She was doing her job, saving lives. She had her hands up, showing she was a medic. They shot her anyway. My daughter died helping others. How can they say she was a threat? She was wearing white, she had the medical symbol, everyone could see she was a paramedic.' Razan's last words: 'I'm going to die.'
witnesses.source: Family testimony to investigators; media interviews

witnesses.name: Dr. Tarek Loubani
witnesses.testimony: Physician shot in legs while treating wounded, wearing clearly marked medical vest: 'I have worked in conflict zones around the world. I have never seen this level of deliberate targeting of medical personnel. We were clearly marked, everyone could see we were doctors and paramedics. They shot us anyway. The injuries I saw‚Äîlegs blown apart, bones shattered‚Äîthese were designed to maim for life.'
witnesses.source: Testimony to Canadian Parliament; media interviews, May 2018

witnesses.name: Yaser Murtaja (before death)
witnesses.testimony: In interview days before being shot dead: 'I film the protests to show the world what is happening here. We wear PRESS vests so the Israeli soldiers know we are journalists. We are not fighters, we are documenting.' Shot in abdomen while wearing clearly marked press vest. Died of wounds. Video shows him clearly identified as press when shot.
witnesses.source: Final interview; Committee to Protect Journalists investigation

witnesses.name: Ban Ki-moon
witnesses.role: Former UN Secretary-General (Deputy Chair, The Elders)
witnesses.testimony: May 2018 statement: 'The scenes from Gaza are heartbreaking. The use of live ammunition against unarmed protesters is unacceptable...Israel has a responsibility to exercise maximum restraint and ensure the protection of civilians. The killing and wounding of thousands of Palestinian demonstrators must be urgently investigated.'

witnesses.name: Zeid Ra'ad Al Hussein
witnesses.role: UN High Commissioner for Human Rights (2014-2018)
witnesses.testimony: March 30, 2018 statement after first day: 'The stark contrast in casualties on both sides is suggestive of a wholly disproportionate response. The mere fact of approaching or crossing a border fence cannot amount to a threat to life or serious injury justifying the use of live ammunition...The use of live ammunition against peaceful protesters clearly violates international human rights law.'

witnesses.name: World Health Organization
witnesses.testimony: Special report on limb injuries: 'The injuries sustained by patients are of a severity not seen before...The bones and soft tissue are pulverized, creating massive wounds...Many patients face multiple surgeries and some will require amputations. This pattern of injuries is unprecedented and extremely concerning, suggesting systematic targeting of lower limbs.'

witnesses.name: Physicians for Human Rights - Israel
witnesses.testimony: After investigation: 'The use of live fire against medical staff...constitutes a grave violation of international humanitarian law. Medical personnel are protected persons under the Geneva Conventions...The Israeli military's actions endanger medical teams and deprive the wounded of life-saving treatment. We call for immediate end to attacks on medical personnel.'

witnesses.name: Breaking the Silence (Israeli soldiers)
witnesses.testimony: Anonymous soldier testimony about orders: 'We were told anyone who approaches the fence is a target. It didn't matter if they were armed or not, if they were kids or medics or press. The orders were clear: shoot to injure, aim for the legs. They wanted to send a message. We shot thousands of people who posed no threat to us. Some of my fellow soldiers celebrated their kill counts.'

commanders.name: Benjamin Netanyahu
commanders.responsibility: Approved military response to protests including rules of engagement permitting lethal force. Defended killings: 'Hamas sends thousands to breach border and murder Israelis. We will defend our border.' Rejected UN Commission findings.

commanders.name: Avigdor Lieberman
commanders.responsibility: Oversaw military operations during protests. Stated April 2018: 'There are no innocents in Gaza.' Approved rules of engagement. Praised soldiers: 'Everyone who was shot‚Äîwas shot because he deserved it.' Resigned November 2018 over ceasefire with Hamas.

commanders.name: Gadi Eisenkot
commanders.responsibility: Top military commander during protests. Responsible for operational decisions and rules of engagement. Defended use of live fire. Later admitted in testimony some soldiers may have violated rules but maintained overall response appropriate.

commanders.name: Ismail Haniyeh
commanders.responsibility: Hamas political leader. Supported protests but did not organize them initially. Later Hamas took more active organizational role. Called for continued protests despite casualties. Rejected criticism that Hamas used civilians as shields.

commanders.name: Ahmed Abu Artema
commanders.responsibility: Independent Palestinian journalist who conceived and helped organize Great March of Return. Advocated for non-violent approach. Vision was peaceful protest to draw attention to blockade and right of return. Has stated protests succeeded in raising awareness despite tragic casualties.

commanders.name: Razan al-Najjar
commanders.responsibility: 21-year-old volunteer paramedic killed June 1, 2018 while treating wounded. Became symbol of Israeli targeting of medical personnel. Her killing documented by video; she was clearly marked as medic with hands raised when shot.

sections.heading: Immediate Impact (2018-2019)
items: 223 Palestinians killed, 28,939 injured over 21 months of largely peaceful protests
Zero Israeli casualties‚Äîstark demonstration that protesters posed no actual threat
UN Commission found 187 of 189 investigated killings unlawful; violations may constitute war crimes or crimes against humanity
International attention focused on Gaza humanitarian crisis and blockade, though no policy changes resulted
122+ Palestinians required limb amputations; 20 were children‚Äîgeneration maimed for life
Razan al-Najjar became international symbol of Israeli targeting of medical personnel
Protests demonstrated Palestinian determination to pursue rights despite lethal response

sections.heading: Long-term Consequences (2019-Present)
items: Total impunity: Zero meaningful prosecutions despite UN findings of systematic violations
Established precedent: Israel could kill protesters with impunity; international community would do nothing
ICC investigation (opened 2021) includes Great March of Return but no charges filed as of 2025
Victims continue suffering: hundreds with permanent disabilities, psychological trauma, lost livelihoods
Gaza blockade continued unabated; none of protests' stated objectives achieved
International law credibility damaged: UN findings completely ignored by Israel and not enforced
Protests entered Palestinian collective memory alongside Nakba, Naksa, Intifadas as symbol of resistance
Medical community horrified by targeting of clearly marked health workers‚Äîunprecedented in modern conflicts

sources.title: Verified Sources & Documentation
sources.introduction: Primary sources include UN Commission of Inquiry comprehensive investigation, human rights organizations, medical documentation, video evidence, and survivor testimonies. UN Commission investigated every single killing on official protest days.

list.name: UN Human Rights Council - Report of the Commission of Inquiry on the protests in the OPT (A/HRC/40/74)
list.description: Comprehensive 289-page investigation led by Santiago Canton. Investigated every killing at designated protest sites on official protest days (March 30-December 31, 2018). Found 187 of 189 killings unlawful. Concluded violations may constitute war crimes or crimes against humanity. Released February 28, 2019.

list.name: OHCHR - Press Release: Israeli snipers shot children and journalists
list.description: Official UN Human Rights Office press release summarizing Commission findings. Details killings of children, journalists, medical personnel. Includes commissioner quotes on lack of justification for killings.

list.name: B'Tselem - Complete Statistics: One Year Since the Gaza 'March of Return'
list.description: Comprehensive database documenting 223 Palestinians killed through December 2019, including 41 children, 3 medics, 2 journalists. Individual incident reports with names, ages, circumstances. Updated statistics through end of protests.

list.name: Physicians for Human Rights - Israel: Attacks on Medical Personnel
list.description: Documentation of attacks on 441 medical personnel including 3 killed. Investigation of Razan al-Najjar killing. Medical analysis of injuries. Calls for protection of medical workers under Geneva Conventions.

list.name: World Health Organization - Gaza Limb Injuries Report
list.description: Special reports on unprecedented pattern of severe lower-limb injuries. Documented 122+ amputations required. Analysis of bullet injuries showing extreme bone and tissue damage. Ongoing health crisis from injuries.

list.name: Committee to Protect Journalists - Journalists Killed in Gaza Protests
list.description: Investigation of killings of Yaser Murtaja and Ahmad Abu Hussein. Documentation of 144 journalists injured. Analysis of targeting of clearly marked press. Calls for accountability for journalist killings.

list.name: Defense for Children International - Palestine: Child Casualties
list.description: Detailed documentation of 41 children killed. Individual case files with circumstances of death. Analysis of violations of Convention on Rights of the Child. Advocacy for accountability.

list.name: UN OCHA - Humanitarian Bulletins on Gaza Protests
list.description: Regular situation reports documenting casualties, injuries, medical responses. Statistics on 28,939 total injuries. Humanitarian impact assessments. Updates throughout protest period.

list.name: Human Rights Watch - Gaza Protests Reports
list.description: Multiple reports documenting excessive use of force, targeting of medical personnel, violations of laws of war. Calls for investigations and accountability.

list.name: Amnesty International - Gaza Protests Documentation
list.description: Reports on use of excessive force, unlawful killings, targeting of medical workers. Analysis under international human rights law. Advocacy for ICC investigation.

list.name: Breaking the Silence - Soldier Testimonies
list.description: Anonymous testimonies from Israeli soldiers who participated in operations during protests. Details on rules of engagement, orders to shoot, perspectives on killings.

list.name: Adalah - Legal Center: Gaza Protests Advocacy
list.description: Legal filings to Israeli courts demanding investigations. Documentation for ICC. Analysis of violations under international law. Representation of victims' families.

alert.text: Methodology: UN Commission investigated every killing on official protest days through Dec 31, 2018, using video evidence, medical records, ballistics analysis, witness interviews. Israel refused cooperation. B'Tselem continued documentation through end of protests December 2019.
